awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of integrated laser scanning/spinning disk confocal microscopy system to advance multidisciplinary research and training at Mount Holyoke College
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Mount Holyoke College to acquire an integrated laser scanning/spinning disk confocal microscopy system that will enhance the diverse research and teaching needs of its faculty. This equipment will considerably strengthen STEM education at the oldest women's college in the country by promoting new and innovative microscopy-associated course offerings across the Life and Physical Science curriculum. Students will be afforded hands-on training with the most current and powerful instrumentation to both prepare them for the job market and enhance their candidacy for graduate-level education. The microscope will also be used as the focus of campus wide events specifically geared towards increasing representation of students of color in STEM fields.

The confocal microscope will transform scientific inquiry of Mount Holyoke faculty spanning a variety of disciplines, organisms, model systems and preparations. The number of undergraduate-driven research activities in biology, neuroscience, chemistry, psychology, and physics will be increased by expanding opportunities for senior thesis research and summer internship projects ranging from fine-scale interrogations of cellular interactions to particle fluid dynamics and intracellular signaling pathways. The versatility of this microscopy system will transform the research and teaching platforms across STEM disciplines at Mount Holyoke College and provide new opportunities that prepare a diverse student body to work in cutting-edge research fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF MOUNT HOLYOKE COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
The award, Acquisition of integrated laser scanning/spinning disk confocal microscopy system (ICM) to advance multidisciplinary research and training at Mount Holyoke College, accomplished its intended intellectual merit and broader impacts, and facilitated the outcomes described herein. The Mount Holyoke faculty used the cutting-edge confocal technology to conduct innovative research across diverse disciplines, while also incorporating it into the scientific curriculum at the College. The ICM was also used at events that specifically targeted underrepresented minorities to widen the pipeline of future scientists to include students often feel marginalized. These College-wide events, in addition to events geared towards outreach within the local community, allowed the scientists of tomorrow to appreciate the aesthetic beauty of the cellular processes that govern the natural world.

The ICM enabled the initiation and continuation of multiple lines of research inquiry from an Mount Holyoke faculty who investigate an array of biological processes. Specifically, these research topics include: 1) Quantifying cell death in Drosophila disease models, 2) Determining the functional integrity of the Drosophila blood-brain barrier, 3) Measuring activation of intracellular signaling cascades in Drosophila using fluorescent reporters, 4) Performing in vivo, live imaging of cellular dynamics in the adult Drosophila brain, 5) Visualizing the morphology and assessing the genetic factors that control the developmental regulation of fat body remodeling in Drosophila, 6) Validating regional specificity of virally-injected DREADD proteins into the hippocampi of mice and rats, in support of reward devaluation experiments in rodents, 7) Assessing the internal structure of fossils from the Cambrian period, 8) Imaging and tracking fluorescently-coupled polystyrene spheres in shear thickening experiments in support of fluid dynamics experiments. These research inquiries led to four publications, numerous student presentations, and honor theses. Together, the diversity of research questions that were enabled by the ICM highlight the transformative effect this instrument had on the research capability at Mount Holyoke College.

In addition to its dramatic effect on research infrastructure at the College, the ICM significantly enhanced science pedagogy in the classroom. Specifically, the ICM was used in active learning modules associated with the following Mount Holyoke courses that span multiple departments: Neuro 221: Research Techniques in Neuroscience, Neuro 324: Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience, Bio 226: Evolution, Coll 321: Fundamentals of Microscopy, and Chem 291: Scientific Illustration and Data Visualization. Together, these course offerings introduced students to new ways of visualizing and analyzing the physical world around them, and allowed students to develop an appreciation for the superior resolving capabilities of confocal microscopy.

The ICM has also impacted how the broader community engages with science, and served to inspire the students of today to become the scientists of tomorrow. Specifically, the ICM was used as a focal point for events designed to increase representation of identity groups that have been historically marginalized in science.  Specifically, the ICM was the highlight of Mount Holyoke STEM-POC recruitment events to inspire curiosity and a passion for science in students of color. The ICM was also incorporated into visits from local high school students who were introduced to the wonders of microscopy as the next generation of scientists became more familiar with college, and the pursuits found within. These activities have firmly entrenched the ICM, and the visual artistry it produces, as a STEM recruitment tool that is impacting the diverse student body at Mount Holyoke, and its surrounding community.

In summary, the ICM has become an indispensable asset that has empowered varied faculty research trajectories, and has enriched educational offerings that train the curious students of today to become the innovative scientists of tomorrow. The beneficial effects of the ICM at Mount Holyoke College will be felt for many years to come.
